abstract: For years, financial industry rules have barred research analysts from pitching initial public offering business, but some say Wall Street is returning to its old ways.
snippet: For years, financial industry rules have barred research analysts from pitching initial public offering business, but some say Wall Street is returning to its old ways.
lead_paragraph: The market for initial public offerings has made a comeback, surging to levels not seen since before the financial crisis. At the same time, concerns have resurfaced over the role of Wall Street research analysts in these lucrative deals.

headline.main: With I.P.O.’s on the Rise, Analysts Get New Scrutiny
headline.print_headline: With I.P.O.’s On the Rise, Analysts Get New Scrutiny

byline.original: By Peter Lattman and Susanne Craig

abstract: People briefed on the matter say an investigation could yield a fine and a reprimand of the bank over the trading blowup known as the “London Whale.”
snippet: People briefed on the matter say an investigation could yield a fine and a reprimand of the bank over the trading blowup known as the “London Whale.”
lead_paragraph: As federal authorities prepare to charge criminally two former JPMorgan Chase employees suspected of misrepresenting a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year, prosecutors in Manhattan are separately exploring ways to penalize the bank over the trading blowup that has come to be known as the “London Whale.”

headline.main: Prosecutors and F.B.I. Examine JPMorgan Over Losses

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

abstract: With I.P.O.’s making a comeback, some analysts say Wall Street is slipping back to its old ways. | Prosecutors are exploring ways to penalize JPMorgan Chase over a trading loss. | A look at the Wall Street experiences of Lawrence H. Summers. | The House Financial Services Committee is sometimes called “the cash committee.”
snippet: With I.P.O.’s making a comeback, some analysts say Wall Street is slipping back to its old ways. | Prosecutors are exploring ways to penalize JPMorgan Chase over a trading loss. | A look at the Wall Street experiences of Lawrence H. Summers. | The...
lead_paragraph: For years, Wall Street research analysts have been barred from pitching initial public offering business. But with the market for I.P.O.’s making a comeback, some analysts say Wall Street is slipping back to its old ways, Peter Lattman and Susanne Craig report in DealBook.

headline.main: Fresh Scrutiny for Wall Street Analysts

abstract: Requiring JPMorgan Chase to admit to violations of securities laws in the case of the so-called London Whale could be a guide for how the S.E.C. would handle such Wall Street cases, the author writes.
snippet: Requiring JPMorgan Chase to admit to violations of securities laws in the case of the so-called London Whale could be a guide for how the S.E.C. would handle such Wall Street cases, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Trades by the so-called London Whale have already cost JPMorgan Chase over $6 billion in losses. They could also result in a precedent that will make the transactions live on in the annals of notoriety, if the Securities and Exchange Commission can extract an admission of wrongdoing from the bank.

headline.main: For S.E.C., Any JPMorgan Settlement Could Serve as a Template
